06eddd04.question: How did the investigation process address the confidentiality of personnel records?
06eddd04.answer: The investigation process addressed the confidentiality of personnel records by stating that these records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is provided to the public during the investigation. Additionally, efforts can be made to protect the privacy of those records even if they become part of the official proceedings.

NOTICE TO CONSUMER 
(Personnel Records) 

 
The Board of Registered Nursing is the licensing and regulatory agency for Registered Nurses in 
California.In that capacity, it reviews the quality of services provided by licensed professionals under its 
jurisdiction.If appropriate, the Board enforces the disciplinary and criminal provisions in the law relating 
to Registered Nurses.This review is conducted through investigation.The Division of Investigation investigators and Board 
experts read and evaluate the personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.These records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is 
provided to the public during the investigation.However, if the investigation reveals improper actions by 
the licensee (consumer), the Board may take action to limit or even revoke the professional license.Personnel records may become part of the official proceedings.Even then, efforts can be made to protect 
the privacy of those records.Consumers may consent to have the Board obtain and review their personnel records by signing the 
“Authorization For Release” form (enclosed).This form also authorizes the Board and the California 
Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General to use the records as evidence in any official 
proceeding against a licensee.A consumer, of course, has the right not to consent to the release of records.However, in that case, the 
Board may take the necessary steps to subpoena the records.By signing the enclosed “Authorization For Release” form, you assist the Board in its effort to investigate 
whether practices fell below the standards required by law.Your cooperation provides a valuable public 
service.INV99-02 (rev 13) 
 
 

 BUSINESS, CONSUMER SERVICES, AND HOUSING AGENCY   •   GOVERNOR GAVIN NEWSOM

NOTICE TO CONSUMER 
(Personnel Records) 

 
The Board of Registered Nursing is the licensing and regulatory agency for Registered Nurses in 
California.In that capacity, it reviews the quality of services provided by licensed professionals under its 
jurisdiction.If appropriate, the Board enforces the disciplinary and criminal provisions in the law relating 
to Registered Nurses.This review is conducted through investigation.The Division of Investigation investigators and Board 
experts read and evaluate the personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.These records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is 
provided to the public during the investigation.However, if the investigation reveals improper actions by 
the licensee (consumer), the Board may take action to limit or even revoke the professional license.Personnel records may become part of the official proceedings.Even then, efforts can be made to protect 
the privacy of those records.Consumers may consent to have the Board obtain and review their personnel records by signing the 
“Authorization For Release” form (enclosed).This form also authorizes the Board and the California 
Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General to use the records as evidence in any official 
proceeding against a licensee.A consumer, of course, has the right not to consent to the release of records.However, in that case, the 
Board may take the necessary steps to subpoena the records.By signing the enclosed “Authorization For Release” form, you assist the Board in its effort to investigate 
whether practices fell below the standards required by law.Your cooperation provides a valuable public 
service.INV99-02 (rev 13) 
 
 

 BUSINESS, CONSUMER SERVICES, AND HOUSING AGENCY   •   GOVERNOR GAVIN NEWSOM

The Board of Registered Nursing is the licensing and regulatory agency for Registered Nurses in 
California.In that capacity, it reviews the quality of services provided by licensed professionals under its 
jurisdiction.If appropriate, the Board enforces the disciplinary and criminal provisions in the law relating 
to Registered Nurses.This review is conducted through investigation.The Division of Investigation investigators and Board 
experts read and evaluate the personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.These records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is 
provided to the public during the investigation.However, if the investigation reveals improper actions by 
the licensee (consumer), the Board may take action to limit or even revoke the professional license.Personnel records may become part of the official proceedings.Even then, efforts can be made to protect 
the privacy of those records.Consumers may consent to have the Board obtain and review their personnel records by signing the 
“Authorization For Release” form (enclosed).This form also authorizes the Board and the California 
Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General to use the records as evidence in any official 
proceeding against a licensee.A consumer, of course, has the right not to consent to the release of records.However, in that case, the 
Board may take the necessary steps to subpoena the records.By signing the enclosed “Authorization For Release” form, you assist the Board in its effort to investigate 
whether practices fell below the standards required by law.Your cooperation provides a valuable public 
service.INV99-02 (rev 13)

6e63c3bb.question: How does the report describe the investigation process for assessing nursing compliance?
6e63c3bb.answer:
The report describes the investigation process for assessing nursing compliance as follows:

1. Review of personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.
2. Evaluation of documentation guidelines for nursing care and compliance with the Code of Conduct.
3. Interviews with complainants, victims, and relevant personnel.
4. Collection of medical records and policies/procedures related to the case.
5. Documentation of time spent on various investigative activities, including report writing, reviewing records, and correspondence.
6. Obtaining consent from consumers to access their personnel records or taking necessary steps to subpoena records if consent is not given.

NOTICE TO CONSUMER 
(Personnel Records) 

 
The Board of Registered Nursing is the licensing and regulatory agency for Registered Nurses in 
California.In that capacity, it reviews the quality of services provided by licensed professionals under its 
jurisdiction.If appropriate, the Board enforces the disciplinary and criminal provisions in the law relating 
to Registered Nurses.This review is conducted through investigation.The Division of Investigation investigators and Board 
experts read and evaluate the personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.These records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is 
provided to the public during the investigation.However, if the investigation reveals improper actions by 
the licensee (consumer), the Board may take action to limit or even revoke the professional license.Personnel records may become part of the official proceedings.Even then, efforts can be made to protect 
the privacy of those records.Consumers may consent to have the Board obtain and review their personnel records by signing the 
“Authorization For Release” form (enclosed).This form also authorizes the Board and the California 
Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General to use the records as evidence in any official 
proceeding against a licensee.A consumer, of course, has the right not to consent to the release of records.However, in that case, the 
Board may take the necessary steps to subpoena the records.By signing the enclosed “Authorization For Release” form, you assist the Board in its effort to investigate 
whether practices fell below the standards required by law.Your cooperation provides a valuable public 
service.INV99-02 (rev 13) 
 
 

 BUSINESS, CONSUMER SERVICES, AND HOUSING AGENCY   •   GOVERNOR GAVIN NEWSOM

NOTICE TO CONSUMER 
(Personnel Records) 

 
The Board of Registered Nursing is the licensing and regulatory agency for Registered Nurses in 
California.In that capacity, it reviews the quality of services provided by licensed professionals under its 
jurisdiction.If appropriate, the Board enforces the disciplinary and criminal provisions in the law relating 
to Registered Nurses.This review is conducted through investigation.The Division of Investigation investigators and Board 
experts read and evaluate the personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.These records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is 
provided to the public during the investigation.However, if the investigation reveals improper actions by 
the licensee (consumer), the Board may take action to limit or even revoke the professional license.Personnel records may become part of the official proceedings.Even then, efforts can be made to protect 
the privacy of those records.Consumers may consent to have the Board obtain and review their personnel records by signing the 
“Authorization For Release” form (enclosed).This form also authorizes the Board and the California 
Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General to use the records as evidence in any official 
proceeding against a licensee.A consumer, of course, has the right not to consent to the release of records.However, in that case, the 
Board may take the necessary steps to subpoena the records.By signing the enclosed “Authorization For Release” form, you assist the Board in its effort to investigate 
whether practices fell below the standards required by law.Your cooperation provides a valuable public 
service.INV99-02 (rev 13)

NOTICE TO CONSUMER 
(Personnel Records) 

 
The Board of Registered Nursing is the licensing and regulatory agency for Registered Nurses in 
California.In that capacity, it reviews the quality of services provided by licensed professionals under its 
jurisdiction.If appropriate, the Board enforces the disciplinary and criminal provisions in the law relating 
to Registered Nurses.This review is conducted through investigation.The Division of Investigation investigators and Board 
experts read and evaluate the personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.These records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is 
provided to the public during the investigation.However, if the investigation reveals improper actions by 
the licensee (consumer), the Board may take action to limit or even revoke the professional license.Personnel records may become part of the official proceedings.Even then, efforts can be made to protect 
the privacy of those records.Consumers may consent to have the Board obtain and review their personnel records by signing the 
“Authorization For Release” form (enclosed).This form also authorizes the Board and the California 
Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General to use the records as evidence in any official 
proceeding against a licensee.A consumer, of course, has the right not to consent to the release of records.However, in that case, the 
Board may take the necessary steps to subpoena the records.By signing the enclosed “Authorization For Release” form, you assist the Board in its effort to investigate 
whether practices fell below the standards required by law.Your cooperation provides a valuable public 
service.INV99-02 (rev 13) 
 
 

 BUSINESS, CONSUMER SERVICES, AND HOUSING AGENCY   •   GOVERNOR GAVIN NEWSOM

NOTICE TO CONSUMER 
(Personnel Records) 

 
The Board of Registered Nursing is the licensing and regulatory agency for Registered Nurses in 
California.In that capacity, it reviews the quality of services provided by licensed professionals under its 
jurisdiction.If appropriate, the Board enforces the disciplinary and criminal provisions in the law relating 
to Registered Nurses.This review is conducted through investigation.The Division of Investigation investigators and Board 
experts read and evaluate the personnel records of individuals who are the subject of an investigation.These records are kept confidential by the Board and no information about the personnel records is 
provided to the public during the investigation.However, if the investigation reveals improper actions by 
the licensee (consumer), the Board may take action to limit or even revoke the professional license.Personnel records may become part of the official proceedings.Even then, efforts can be made to protect 
the privacy of those records.Consumers may consent to have the Board obtain and review their personnel records by signing the 
“Authorization For Release” form (enclosed).This form also authorizes the Board and the California 
Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General to use the records as evidence in any official 
proceeding against a licensee.A consumer, of course, has the right not to consent to the release of records.However, in that case, the 
Board may take the necessary steps to subpoena the records.By signing the enclosed “Authorization For Release” form, you assist the Board in its effort to investigate 
whether practices fell below the standards required by law.Your cooperation provides a valuable public 
service.INV99-02 (rev 13) 
 
 

 BUSINESS, CONSUMER SERVICES, AND HOUSING AGENCY   •   GOVERNOR GAVIN NEWSOM
